ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: -C# coding, learning unity, scripting, working with other peers for a personal project.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would be nice if we had mandated weekly or biweekly meetings with the advisers/department, just so there were some guidelines.

The Computing and the Arts program needs to get itself together. Without a DUS this semester, not that she makes any real efforts when she is around, and with practically no other support among faculty or administration, it was all sort of a joke.

-Not very structured or organized, but that's dependent on the student (me). 
-I wish we could have meet with all the students of CPAR, or at least a different group of people per meeting, as it would have been more productive and insightful.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You have to take it to graduate. So, do.

This class is required for Computing and the Arts students. You simply meet with an advisor once every week, and report your progress each week. At the end of the semester, you must submit a report on your project, including research, inspirations, the process, results, and future steps for the project.
